definitions: use physical strength or power to make someone do something against their will
push or drive something with great effort through resistance or obstacles
produce something with effort in an unnatural or strained manner
examples: The police forced the protestors to leave the area
Nobody can force you to sign that contract today
She forced the key into the rusty old lock
They forced their way through the crowded marketplace
He forced a smile despite feeling utterly miserable inside
Don't force your voice when singing those high notes

definitions: cross a river or stream at a shallow place by walking or driving through the water
examples: The pioneers had to ford several rivers during their journey
We carefully forded the stream on horseback yesterday morning

definitions: prepare someone in advance for danger or attack by providing weapons, knowledge, or resources
examples: The general forearmed his troops before the winter campaign
Knowledge of their tactics will forearm us against deception

definitions: predict or estimate a future event or trend based on current data or analysis
predict weather conditions for a future time based on meteorological data
examples: Economists forecast a recession for the coming fiscal year
The company forecasts strong growth in emerging markets globally
The meteorologist forecasts rain for the entire weekend ahead
They forecast temperatures dropping below freezing tonight across regions

definitions: decide not to have or do something pleasant or valuable that is available
come before something in time, order, or position in a sequence
examples: She decided to forego dessert to maintain her diet
Many students forego vacations to save money for tuition
The introduction foregoes the main chapters of the book
These symptoms typically forego the onset of the disease

definitions: bring something into prominence or make it the most noticeable or important element
examples: The director foregrounds social issues in her latest film
The report foregrounds environmental concerns over economic growth factors

definitions: realize or predict that something will happen in the future before it actually occurs
examples: Nobody could foresee the economic crisis that followed later
She foresaw difficulties in implementing the new policy immediately

definitions: be a warning or indication of a future event through subtle signs or clues
examples: Dark clouds foreshadowed the approaching storm that evening clearly
His early symptoms foreshadowed a more serious illness developing later

definitions: plant trees on an area of land to create or establish a forest
examples: The government plans to forest the barren hillsides extensively
They forested the abandoned farmland with native pine species

definitions: prevent something from happening or someone from doing something by taking action in advance
examples: Quick negotiations forestalled a major strike at the factory
The new regulations forestall any attempts at tax evasion

definitions: lose or be deprived of something as a penalty for wrongdoing or breach of rules
examples: The team forfeited the game for using ineligible players
She forfeited her deposit when she cancelled the reservation

definitions: shape metal by heating it in a fire and hammering it into form
produce a fraudulent copy or imitation of a document or signature illegally
create or develop something strong and enduring through persistent effort over time
examples: The blacksmith forged horseshoes in his workshop all day
They forge steel components for the automotive industry regularly
Someone forged his signature on several company checks recently
The criminals forged passports to cross international borders illegally
The two countries forged a lasting alliance through diplomacy
She forged ahead with her plans despite numerous obstacles

definitions: be unable to recall information or events from memory when trying to remember
accidentally leave something behind or fail to bring something that was needed
examples: I completely forgot her name during the important introduction
Don't forget to lock the door when leaving tonight
She forgot her umbrella at the restaurant last night
He always forgets his keys somewhere in the house

definitions: stop feeling angry or resentful toward someone for an offense or mistake they made
cancel or decide not to require payment of a debt or financial obligation
examples: She forgave him for breaking her favorite vase yesterday
Please forgive me for arriving so late to dinner
The bank forgave the loan after the natural disaster
The government forgave student debt for public service workers

definitions: decide not to have or do something desirable that one could have or do
examples: They decided to forgo the expensive vacation this year
She will forgo coffee during her pregnancy for safety

definitions: divide into two or more branches or separate paths going in different directions
pay money especially when reluctant or forced to do so by circumstances
examples: The river forks into two streams near the mountain
The road forks about three miles ahead of us
He had to fork out thousands for car repairs
Parents fork over huge sums for college tuition annually

definitions: make or create something by shaping or bringing parts together into a whole
begin to exist or develop gradually from separate elements combining naturally together
arrange people or things in a particular pattern, line, or organized structure
examples: She formed the clay into a beautiful vase shape
They formed a committee to address the pressing issue
Clouds are forming on the western horizon this afternoon
Ice forms on the lake during cold winter nights
The students formed a circle for the group activity
Soldiers formed ranks on the parade ground this morning

definitions: give something legal or official status by completing necessary procedures or documentation properly
examples: They formalized their partnership with a written legal agreement
The company formalized its policies in an employee handbook

definitions: arrange text, data, or visual elements in a particular layout or structured presentation
prepare a computer disk or drive for use by organizing its storage structure
examples: Please format the document according to company guidelines precisely
She formatted the report with headers and page numbers
You need to format the hard drive before installing
He formatted the USB drive to remove all data

definitions: create or develop a method, theory, or strategy through careful thought and planning
express an idea or concept in a clear, precise, and systematic way
examples: Scientists formulated a new theory about climate change patterns
The team formulated a strategy for market expansion overseas
She carefully formulated her response to avoid any misunderstanding
The lawyer formulated the argument in compelling legal terms

definitions: abandon or leave someone or something entirely, especially when they need support most
examples: He forsook his family to pursue his selfish ambitions
She would never forsake her principles for monetary gain

definitions: strengthen a place or position with defensive works to protect against attack
add vitamins, minerals, or other nutrients to food to increase nutritional value
examples: They fortified the castle walls against the coming siege
The army fortified its position with trenches and barriers
Manufacturers fortify breakfast cereals with essential vitamins and minerals
The government fortifies flour with folic acid for health

definitions: encourage or promote the development or growth of ideas, feelings, or relationships
take care of and raise a child that is not one's own by birth
examples: Good teachers foster creativity in their students every day
The program fosters understanding between different cultural communities effectively
They fostered three children over the past ten years
She decided to foster teenagers who need stable homes

definitions: make something dirty or polluted with harmful or unpleasant substances contaminating it
commit an illegal action against an opponent in sports breaking the established rules
examples: Industrial waste fouled the river for many miles downstream
Oil spills fouled the pristine beaches along the coast
The player fouled his opponent during the crucial play
She was fouled three times in the basketball game

definitions: establish or originate an institution, organization, or settlement as its first creator
examples: They founded the university over two hundred years ago
She founded a charity to help homeless families locally

definitions: fail completely or come to nothing despite initial promise or strong efforts
fill with water and sink, especially referring to ships or boats at sea
examples: The business foundered after losing its major client suddenly
Peace talks foundered on the issue of territorial disputes
The ship foundered in heavy seas during the storm
Several boats foundered near the rocky coastline last night

definitions: confuse, perplex, or deceive someone through cleverness or cunning behavior and tactics
examples: The complicated instructions completely foxed everyone in the class
His evasive answers foxed the reporters at the conference

definitions: perform a ballroom dance in 4/4 time with slow-slow-quick-quick rhythm patterns
examples: They learned to foxtrot at their wedding dance lessons
The couple foxtrots beautifully across the ballroom floor tonight

definitions: divide or break something into smaller parts or portions of the original whole
examples: The company fractioned its shares to make them affordable
They fractioned the land into smaller parcels for sale

definitions: break or cause to break, especially a hard material like bone or rock
damage or destroy the unity or strength of something like relationships or organizations
examples: She fractured her wrist in the skiing accident yesterday
The earthquake fractured the building's foundation causing major damage
The scandal fractured the political party into opposing factions
Disagreements fractured their friendship beyond any possible repair attempts

definitions: break or cause to break into small pieces or parts losing original wholeness
examples: The ancient pottery fragmented when archaeologists tried moving it
Bombing fragmented the building into dangerous rubble and debris

definitions: construct the basic structure or skeleton of a building using timber or metal
formulate, express, or present ideas, questions, or issues in particular words carefully
produce false evidence against an innocent person to make them appear guilty
examples: Workers framed the house in just two weeks time
They framed the addition with steel beams for strength
She carefully framed her question to avoid causing offense
The report frames the issue as an economic problem
The corrupt officers framed him for the robbery downtown
Someone framed her by planting evidence in her car

definitions: grant or obtain the right to operate a business using another company's established system
examples: The company franchised its restaurants across the entire country
They decided to franchise their successful business model internationally

definitions: place an official mark on mail to show that postage has been paid or is free
examples: The post office franked all the letters this morning
Government offices can frank their official mail without stamps

definitions: unravel or wear away at the edges of fabric through use or friction
cause strain, irritation, or deterioration in nerves, temper, or relationships over time
examples: The rope began to fray after months of use
Constant washing frayed the edges of her favorite sweater
The long wait frayed everyone's nerves at the airport
Political tensions frayed relations between the neighboring countries significantly

definitions: react with extreme or irrational emotion, especially fear, panic, or excitement suddenly
cause someone to experience extreme emotional distress or unusual excitement about something
examples: She completely freaked when she saw the huge spider
Don't freak out about the test results just yet
The horror movie really freaked him out last night
That strange noise would freak anyone in this darkness

definitions: release someone or something from captivity, confinement, or slavery into liberty
remove restrictions, obligations, or burdens from someone allowing greater freedom of action
examples: They freed all the prisoners after the peace treaty
Animal activists freed the dolphins from the marine park
The new law frees small businesses from excessive regulations
Retirement freed him to pursue his artistic passions fully

definitions: work for different companies at different times rather than being permanently employed
examples: She decided to freelance after leaving her corporate job
Many writers freelance for multiple publications to earn income

definitions: turn into ice or another solid as a result of extreme cold temperature
become motionless suddenly, especially because of fear, shock, or seeing danger approaching
preserve food or biological material by storing it at very low temperatures
examples: Water freezes at zero degrees Celsius under normal pressure
The lake froze completely during the harsh winter months
The deer froze when it heard footsteps approaching nearby
Everyone froze in place when the alarm suddenly sounded
We freeze vegetables from our garden every summer harvest
Scientists freeze tissue samples for future research and analysis

definitions: transport goods in bulk by truck, train, ship, or aircraft for commercial purposes
examples: The company freights products across the country every day
They freight heavy machinery to construction sites using trucks

definitions: visit a particular place often or habitually as a regular customer or visitor
examples: She frequents the local coffee shop every morning weekday
Celebrities frequent this exclusive restaurant on special weekend occasions

definitions: be constantly or visibly worried or anxious about something that may happen
gradually wear away or consume something through persistent rubbing or gnawing action
examples: She frets about her children whenever they travel alone
Don't fret over things you cannot control or change
The river fretted away the stone over many centuries
Rust had fretted the metal gate into fragile pieces

definitions: make someone afraid or anxious by threatening them or causing fear suddenly
examples: The loud thunder frightened the small children during bedtime
Don't frighten the horses with sudden movements or noises

definitions: decorate or border something with hanging threads, tassels, or strips as ornamental edging
examples: She fringed the curtains with golden tassels for elegance
Trees fringe the lake creating a natural scenic boundary

definitions: search someone for concealed weapons or illegal items by running hands over clothing
move around playfully and energetically with quick, lively movements showing excitement or joy
examples: Security guards frisked everyone entering the courthouse this morning
Police frisked the suspect for weapons before making arrest
The puppies frisked around the yard chasing each other
Lambs frisk in the meadow on warm spring mornings

definitions: play and move about cheerfully, excitedly, or energetically in a carefree manner
examples: Children frolicked in the park during their summer vacation
Dolphins frolic in the waves near the boat regularly

definitions: have the front toward or be positioned facing a particular direction or place
lead or be the most prominent member of a group, band, or organization
examples: The house fronts the ocean with spectacular coastal views
Several shops front onto the main pedestrian shopping street
She fronts a successful rock band touring internationally now
He fronted the campaign for environmental protection last year

definitions: cover with frost or a thin layer of ice crystals from freezing moisture
cover a cake or pastry with icing or frosting as decoration and sweetening
examples: Cold weather frosted the car windows overnight completely throughout
Winter mornings frost the grass with delicate ice crystals
She carefully frosted the birthday cake with chocolate icing
The baker frosts dozens of cupcakes every morning early

definitions: produce or cause to produce a mass of small bubbles or foam on liquid
examples: The cappuccino machine froths milk perfectly every single time
Waves frothed against the rocky shore during high tide

definitions: produce fruit as part of a plant's natural reproductive cycle and growth
examples: The apple trees fruit abundantly in early autumn season
These tomato plants should fruit within eight weeks typically
